faqs.answer: Citizens of Belarus, Burundi, Central African Republic, Cuba, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Iran, Iraq, Lebanon, Libya Nicaragua, North Korea, Russia, Somalia, South Sudan, Sudan, Syria, Ukraine, Venezuela, Yemen, and Zimbabwe. faqs.question: Where should I register my company?
faqs.answer: US Residents: If you are a US resident, your best bet is to register in the state where you live and work, rather than secondary state where you do not operate in. If, on the other hand, you want to prepare your startup for Angel and VC investments, we recommend that you incorporate your company as a corporation in Delaware and  foreign qualify the business in the state where you conduct business. Normally, this refers to the state where the founders are located and is often the home of one of the founders.

faqs.answer: Absolutely! US LLCs, C-Corporations and UK LTDs have a very flexible structure that is ideal for global companies, startups, freelancers, agencies, and digital nomads. This is same with the Canadian Federal Corporation

faqs.answer: You will be issued a Federal Reserve Business Bank account by our banking partners for non resident founders. All business accounts for USA, UK and Canada have Business Checking, ACH and Wire features for global settlements

faqs.question: Why should I start my company in the USA, UK or Canada?
faqs.answer: Access to U.S., UK and Canadian based customers, venture capital, tax benefits, banks, accelerators, payment providers and lines of credit are among the benefits of incorporating a business in the United States, United Kingdom and Canada.

faqs.question: Should I form a LLC or Corporation?
faqs.answer: There are few factors to consider, but in general, you will choose between being a tax efficient LLC or investor-friendly C–Corporation (Inc.). If you plan to raise funding soon, a C–Corporation is a great option; otherwise, incorporate as an LLC for a simpler business structure, reduced paperwork and potential U.S. federal tax exemption.

faqs.answer: Our default State of Incorporation is Colorado due to the low startup fees beginning at $350 for LLCs

faqs.answer: You don't have to physically visit the United States. When it comes to creating a company, we do everything remotely. This means that you can set up a company from from wherever in the world.
